title: About Us

sections.sectionContent: The history of the Vedanta movement in America goes back to the time of the Chicago World's Parliament of Religions, held in conjunction with the Columbian Exposition of 1893. At that time Swami Vivekananda, foremost disciple of Sri Ramakrishna, was invited as the Hindu delegate. America's response to his heroic Chicago Addresses at the 1893 Parliament of Religions is legendary. From that time onward, Swami Vivekananda lectured throughout the country and founded two Vedanta Societies — one in New York and another in San Francisco – and laid the groundwork for more American Vedanta centers to follow.

sections.sectionTitle: Vedanta Movement in the Dallas-Fort Worth Area
sections.sectionContent: The Vedanta movement in the Dallas-Fort Worth area began in the 1960s, when monks of the Ramakrishna Order first visited the area. Many of these swamis came from Vedanta Societies in America, but others came from abroad – India, Africa, and Europe to name a few places. The initial audiences in Dallas were a mix – local residents and a few immigrants or students from India. Meetings were usually held in churches or universities, and the guest swamis lectured on Vedanta's relevance as a rational, practical philosophy for conducting one's spiritual and day-to-day life. Some of the early swamis were Swami Ranganathananda, former President of the Ramakrishna Order of India, Swami Bhashyananda, Minister of the Chicago Vedanta Society, and Swami Nihshreyasananda from Rhodesia.

sections.sectionTitle: Ramakrishna Vedanta Society of North Texas
sections.sectionContent:
The Irving location is convenient for the Dallas-Fort Worth-area devotees and is also near the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport. So on March 3, 2007 – in the presence of over a hundred devotees – Swami Swahananda inaugurated the monastery and chapel of the Ramakrishna Vedanta Society of North Texas, at 119 W. Scotland Drive, in Irving, Texas. Swami Sarvadevananda performed the consecration ceremony.


And so, the history of the Ramakrishna Vedanta Society of North Texas remains a work in progress and a work towards progress, both individual and collective, in spiritual and social advancement.

sections.sectionTitle: Mission of the Ramakrishna Vedanta Society
sections.sectionContent: The primary aim of the Ramakrishna Vedanta Society is personal development of the individual through spiritual practices as taught by Sri Ramakrishna and propagated by Swami Vivekananda and Sri Sarada Devi. Its mission is dedicated to a spirit of tolerance, love, service, and harmony among people.

We encourage people interested in learning more about the philosophy and practice of Vedanta to attend some of the Society's events. Those who would like to become regular attendees are welcome to do so and participate in the Center's activities.


There is no formal membership or membership dues; however we encourage attendees to contribute to the activities of the Society since they are supported by voluntary contributions only. These contributions are tax deductible under Section 501 (c) (3) of the IRS code.


Please contact us at dfwvedanta@gmail.com if you have any questions, suggestions or comments.



**All contributions are tax deductible.**

body:
## Vedanta Movement in America

The history of the Vedanta movement in America goes back to the time of the Chicago Worldss Parliament of Religions, held in conjunction with the Columbian Exposition of 1893. At that time Swami Vivekananda, foremost disciple of Sri Ramakrishna, was invited as the Hindu delegate. America's response to his heroic Chicago Addresses at the 1893 Parliament of Religions is legendary. From that time onward, Swami Vivekananda lectured throughout the country and founded two Vedanta Societies — one in New York and another in San Francisco – and laid the groundwork for more American Vedanta centers to follow.

## Vedanta Movement in the Dallas-Fort Worth Area

The Vedanta movement in the Dallas-Fort Worth area began in the 1960s, when monks of the Ramakrishna Order first visited the area. Many of these swamis came from Vedanta Societies in America, but others came from abroad – India, Africa, and Europe to name a few places. The initial audiences in Dallas were a mix – local residents and a few immigrants or students from India. Meetings were usually held in churches or universities, and the guest swamis lectured on Vedanta's relevance as a rational, practical philosophy for conducting one's spiritual and day-to-day life. Some of the early swamis were Swami Ranganathananda, former President of the Ramakrishna Order of India, Swami Bhashyananda, Minister of the Chicago Vedanta Society, and Swami Nihshreyasananda from Rhodesia.

## Ramakrishna Vedanta Society of North Texas

The Irving location is convenient for the Dallas-Fort Worth-area devotees and is also near the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport. So on March 3, 2007 – in the presence of over a hundred devotees – Swami Swahananda inaugurated the monastery and chapel of the Ramakrishna Vedanta Society of North Texas, at 119 W. Scotland Drive, in Irving, Texas. Swami Sarvadevananda performed the consecration ceremony.

And so, the history of the Ramakrishna Vedanta Society of North Texas remains a work in progress and a work towards progress, both individual and collective, in spiritual and social advancement.

## Mission of the Ramakrishna Vedanta Society

The primary aim of the Ramakrishna Vedanta Society is personal development of the individual through spiritual practices as taught by Sri Ramakrishna and propagated by Swami Vivekananda and Sri Sarada Devi. Its mission is dedicated to a spirit of tolerance, love, service, and harmony among people.

## Join Us

We encourage people interested in learning more about the philosophy and practice of Vedanta to attend some of the Society's events. Those who would like to become regular attendees are welcome to do so and participate in the Center's activities.

There is no formal membership or membership dues; however we encourage attendees to contribute to the activities of the Society since they are supported by voluntary contributions only. These contributions are tax deductible under Section 501 (c) (3) of the IRS code.

Please contact us at dfwvedanta@gmail.com if you have any questions, suggestions or comments.

**All contributions are tax deductible.**

title: Ask a Question
metaDescription: Have a question about Vedanta philosophy, meditation, or our programs? Ask us anything and we'll get back to you.
heroSubtitle: We're here to help answer your questions about Vedanta
body:
## Have a Question?

Whether you're curious about Vedanta philosophy, meditation practices, our programs, or spiritual life in general, we welcome your questions. Our community members and teachers are here to help guide you on your spiritual journey.

Please fill out the form below with your email address and your question. We'll respond as soon as possible.

### Common Questions

**What is Vedanta?**

Vedanta is the philosophical foundation of Hinduism, based on the ancient Upanishads. It teaches the ultimate unity of individual soul with the Universal Soul. [Learn more about Vedanta](vedanta.html).

**Do I need to be Hindu to attend your programs?**

Not at all! Vedanta is universal in its approach and welcomes people of all faiths, backgrounds, and beliefs. Our doors are open to anyone seeking spiritual growth and understanding.

**Are your programs suitable for beginners?**

Yes! We offer programs for all levels, from complete beginners to advanced practitioners. Our [meditation classes](meditation.html) and [lectures](lectures.html) are accessible to everyone.

**How can I support your organization?**

We appreciate your support! You can [donate online](donate.html), volunteer at our events, or simply attend our programs and spread the word about Vedanta.

title: Calendar
body:
Upcoming Events & Programs

Every Sunday | 11:00 AM - 12:30 PM

Silent meditation followed by spiritual discourse and discussion. All are welcome to join us for this inspiring weekly gathering.

Every Thursday | 7:00 PM - 8:30 PM

In-depth study of Patanjali's Yoga Sutras and practical meditation techniques. Open to both beginners and experienced practitioners.

Friday 7:00 PM - Saturday 8:00 PM

Join us for a transformative weekend retreat with inspiring talks on Vedantic philosophy, guided meditation sessions, and opportunities for personal spiritual guidance.

Annual food drive to serve our community in the spirit of Swami Vivekananda's teachings of service to humanity. Donations accepted all week.

Special worship program celebrating Maha Shivaratri with traditional rituals, meditation, and spiritual discourse on Lord Shiva's significance in Vedanta.

Celebration of Sri Ramakrishna's birth anniversary with special puja, devotional singing, and talks on his life and teachings.

Intensive meditation and study retreats led by visiting monastics from the Ramakrishna Order.

Traditional observances of major Hindu festivals and birthdays of spiritual luminaries.

Special talks by scholars and monastics on various aspects of Vedanta philosophy and practice.

Opportunities to serve the community through food drives, charitable activities, and outreach programs.

Subscribe to our newsletter to receive updates about upcoming events and programs

title: Children's Program

sections.sectionContent:
Our Children's Program aims to instill spiritual and moral values in young children through stories, songs, activities, and interactive lessons. We help children develop character, compassion, and an understanding of their cultural and spiritual heritage.


Classes are conducted in a warm, loving environment where children learn about the great spiritual teachers of India, practice meditation and yoga, and develop qualities such as truthfulness, kindness, courage, and respect for all.

Our Children's Program runs concurrently with the Sunday service, allowing parents to attend the adult program while children participate in age-appropriate activities.




### Sunday Classes

Every Sunday | 11:00 AM - 12:30 PM


Classes are divided by age groups to ensure appropriate content and engagement for all children.



**Age Groups:**



- Younger Children (Ages 5-8)

- Older Children (Ages 9-12)

- Teens (Ages 13+)

We welcome all children to participate in our program. There is no registration fee, and all materials are provided. Parents are encouraged to support their children's spiritual education by reinforcing the values and lessons learned at home.


For more information about our Children's Program or to register your child, please contact us or visit us on Sunday.



Contact Us

body:
## Building Character Through Spiritual Values

Our Children's Program aims to instill spiritual and moral values in young children through stories, songs, activities, and interactive lessons. We help children develop character, compassion, and an understanding of their cultural and spiritual heritage.


Classes are conducted in a warm, loving environment where children learn about the great spiritual teachers of India, practice meditation and yoga, and develop qualities such as truthfulness, kindness, courage, and respect for all.

## Class Schedule

Our Children's Program runs concurrently with the Sunday service, allowing parents to attend the adult program while children participate in age-appropriate activities.




### Sunday Classes

Every Sunday | 11:00 AM - 12:30 PM


Classes are divided by age groups to ensure appropriate content and engagement for all children.



**Age Groups:**



- Younger Children (Ages 5-8)

- Older Children (Ages 9-12)

- Teens (Ages 13+)

## Join Our Program

We welcome all children to participate in our program. There is no registration fee, and all materials are provided. Parents are encouraged to support their children's spiritual education by reinforcing the values and lessons learned at home.


For more information about our Children's Program or to register your child, please contact us or visit us on Sunday.



Contact Us

title: Contact Us
heroSubtitle: We'd love to hear from you

title: Directions
heroSubtitle: Find your way to our center

sections.sectionContent:
Ample free parking is available on the premises. Please park in the designated areas and be mindful of neighbors' driveways and property.


During busy Sunday services and special events, additional parking may be available on the street. Please observe all posted parking regulations.


If you have mobility concerns or require accessible parking, please contact us in advance so we can ensure appropriate accommodation.

**Dress Code:** We encourage modest, respectful attire. Traditional Indian clothing is welcome but not required.


**Footwear:** Please remove your shoes before entering the chapel and meditation areas. Shoe racks are provided near the entrance.


**Punctuality:** Sunday services begin promptly at 11:00 AM with silent meditation. We encourage arriving a few minutes early to settle in.


**Mobile Devices:** Please silence all phones and electronic devices before entering the meditation hall.


**Children:** Children are always welcome. A dedicated Children's Program runs during Sunday services for ages 5 and up.


**First-Time Visitors:** Please feel free to introduce yourself to anyone! We're happy to answer questions and help you feel at home.

body:
## Our Location



## Parking Information

Ample free parking is available on the premises. Please park in the designated areas and be mindful of neighbors' driveways and property.


During busy Sunday services and special events, additional parking may be available on the street. Please observe all posted parking regulations.


If you have mobility concerns or require accessible parking, please contact us in advance so we can ensure appropriate accommodation.

## Visitor Guidelines

**Dress Code:** We encourage modest, respectful attire. Traditional Indian clothing is welcome but not required.


**Footwear:** Please remove your shoes before entering the chapel and meditation areas. Shoe racks are provided near the entrance.


**Punctuality:** Sunday services begin promptly at 11:00 AM with silent meditation. We encourage arriving a few minutes early to settle in.


**Mobile Devices:** Please silence all phones and electronic devices before entering the meditation hall.


**Children:** Children are always welcome. A dedicated Children's Program runs during Sunday services for ages 5 and up.


**First-Time Visitors:** Please feel free to introduce yourself to anyone! We're happy to answer questions and help you feel at home.

title: Donate
heroSubtitle: Your contribution helps us serve the community

sections.sectionContent:
The Ramakrishna Vedanta Society of North Texas is a non-profit organization dedicated to spreading the timeless teachings of Vedanta and serving the community through spiritual education and charitable activities.


All our programs and services are offered free of charge. We rely entirely on the generous donations of our members and well-wishers to sustain our activities and maintain our center.


All donations are tax-deductible under Section 501(c)(3) of the IRS code.

We are currently working towards expanding our facilities with the construction of Vivekananda Hall, a dedicated space for larger gatherings, retreats, and community programs.


This new hall will enable us to serve more people and offer enhanced programs for spiritual growth and community engagement.


For more information about contributing to this special project, please contact us.

body:
## Make a Difference

The Ramakrishna Vedanta Society of North Texas is a non-profit organization dedicated to spreading the timeless teachings of Vedanta and serving the community through spiritual education and charitable activities.


All our programs and services are offered free of charge. We rely entirely on the generous donations of our members and well-wishers to sustain our activities and maintain our center.


All donations are tax-deductible under Section 501(c)(3) of the IRS code.

## Vivekananda Hall Project

We are currently working towards expanding our facilities with the construction of Vivekananda Hall, a dedicated space for larger gatherings, retreats, and community programs.


This new hall will enable us to serve more people and offer enhanced programs for spiritual growth and community engagement.


For more information about contributing to this special project, please contact us.

title: Online Lectures
heroSubtitle: Watch our spiritual talks and discourses

sections.sectionContent:
Watch inspiring lectures, spiritual discourses, and teachings from our Sunday services and special programs. Our YouTube channel features talks on Vedanta philosophy, meditation techniques, and the teachings of Sri Ramakrishna, Holy Mother Sarada Devi, and Swami Vivekananda.







                            Visit Our YouTube Channel

Many of our lectures are recorded during our Sunday services. We welcome you to join us in person every Sunday at 11:00 AM for meditation and spiritual discourse.


Can't attend in person? Selected lectures are uploaded to our YouTube channel so you can watch from anywhere in the world.



View Schedule

title: Meditation

sections.sectionContent:
Throughout the year, we host intensive meditation retreats led by visiting monastics. These retreats provide an opportunity for deeper practice and spiritual growth in a supportive environment.


Retreats typically include guided meditation sessions, spiritual instruction, and time for personal practice. Check our calendar for upcoming retreat dates.

### What is Raja Yoga?

Raja Yoga, often called the "royal path," is the yoga of meditation and mental control. The term comes from "raja" meaning king or royal, suggesting it is the supreme yoga that governs the mind.


The classical text of Raja Yoga is Patanjali's Yoga Sutras, which outlines an eight-fold path (Ashtanga Yoga) for achieving mental clarity and spiritual realization:




1. Yama (Ethical Restraints)
Non-violence, truthfulness, non-stealing, continence, and non-possessiveness.




2. Niyama (Observances)
Purity, contentment, austerity, self-study, and surrender to God.




3. Asana (Posture)
A steady and comfortable sitting position for meditation.




4. Pranayama (Breath Control)
Regulation of breath to control vital energy and calm the mind.




5. Pratyahara (Sense Withdrawal)
Withdrawing the senses from external objects to focus inward.




6. Dharana (Concentration)
Focusing the mind on a single point or object.




7. Dhyana (Meditation)
Sustained, uninterrupted flow of concentration.




8. Samadhi (Absorption)
Complete absorption in the object of meditation, leading to self-realization.




Our weekly study circle explores these principles through reading, discussion, and guided practice.

body:
## Silent Meditation



## Meditation Retreats

Throughout the year, we host intensive meditation retreats led by visiting monastics. These retreats provide an opportunity for deeper practice and spiritual growth in a supportive environment.


Retreats typically include guided meditation sessions, spiritual instruction, and time for personal practice. Check our calendar for upcoming retreat dates.

## Raja Yoga Study Circle

### What is Raja Yoga?

Raja Yoga, often called the "royal path," is the yoga of meditation and mental control. The term comes from "raja" meaning king or royal, suggesting it is the supreme yoga that governs the mind.


The classical text of Raja Yoga is Patanjali's Yoga Sutras, which outlines an eight-fold path (Ashtanga Yoga) for achieving mental clarity and spiritual realization:




1. Yama (Ethical Restraints)
Non-violence, truthfulness, non-stealing, continence, and non-possessiveness.




2. Niyama (Observances)
Purity, contentment, austerity, self-study, and surrender to God.




3. Asana (Posture)
A steady and comfortable sitting position for meditation.




4. Pranayama (Breath Control)
Regulation of breath to control vital energy and calm the mind.




5. Pratyahara (Sense Withdrawal)
Withdrawing the senses from external objects to focus inward.




6. Dharana (Concentration)
Focusing the mind on a single point or object.




7. Dhyana (Meditation)
Sustained, uninterrupted flow of concentration.




8. Samadhi (Absorption)
Complete absorption in the object of meditation, leading to self-realization.




Our weekly study circle explores these principles through reading, discussion, and guided practice.

## Getting Started with Meditation

title: Sri Ramakrishna

sections.sectionContent:
India, with her wealth of spiritual tradition, has produced many spiritual giants. One of the greatest was Ramakrishna. His life was a testament to truth, universality, love and purity.


Born in 1836 in a rural village outside Calcutta, Ramakrishna even as a boy naturally gravitated toward leading a spiritual life. This tendency only intensified as he grew older. When as a young man he became a temple priest, he was seized by an unquenchable thirst for union with God, and he immersed himself in intense meditation and other spiritual practices.

Ramakrishna was constantly absorbed in the thought of God. He would often go into high spiritual states where he would merge with the Infinite Reality. For him, the Vedantic teaching of unity of all existence was more than theory; he literally saw, and knew, this to be true.


In his thirst for the divine, Ramakrishna followed different religious paths including various branches of Hinduism. Not content to stop there, however, he also practiced Islam and later meditated deeply on Christ, experiencing the same divine Reality through these non-Hindu paths. Thus, he came to the conclusion, based on his direct experience, that all religions lead to the same goal.


In addition, through his many Sikh devotees, he learned of their faith and its great founders, and he was told of the wonderful life and teachings of the Buddha. This exposure to Sikhism and Buddhism further confirmed his experience of the universality of spiritual truth.

Ramakrishna's love for humanity was limitless. He often said human beings were the highest manifestations of God. His disciples saw this love firsthand, and the monastic order Ramakrishna inspired achieved the distinction of being the first order in India to serve humanity. Service to God in humankind is one of the foremost ideals of the Ramakrishna Order.


Among his many other noteworthy characteristics were his universality and childlike purity, his intense sincerity, his vast knowledge of things spiritual and human (which came not from book-learning but from direct perception), and his extraordinary power to transform lives.

Ramakrishna's teachings regarding the highest truths of spiritual life were delivered in the simplest language and were punctuated by parables and homely metaphors as illustrations. Many noted writers and philosophers— Mahatma Gandhi, Leo Tolstoy, Aldous Huxley, Christopher Isherwood, Thomas Merton, Arnold Toynbee, Joseph Campbell—have been deeply impressed and influenced by him.

body:
## 

India, with her wealth of spiritual tradition, has produced many spiritual giants. One of the greatest was Ramakrishna. His life was a testament to truth, universality, love and purity.


Born in 1836 in a rural village outside Calcutta, Ramakrishna even as a boy naturally gravitated toward leading a spiritual life. This tendency only intensified as he grew older. When as a young man he became a temple priest, he was seized by an unquenchable thirst for union with God, and he immersed himself in intense meditation and other spiritual practices.

## Spiritual Realization

Ramakrishna was constantly absorbed in the thought of God. He would often go into high spiritual states where he would merge with the Infinite Reality. For him, the Vedantic teaching of unity of all existence was more than theory; he literally saw, and knew, this to be true.


In his thirst for the divine, Ramakrishna followed different religious paths including various branches of Hinduism. Not content to stop there, however, he also practiced Islam and later meditated deeply on Christ, experiencing the same divine Reality through these non-Hindu paths. Thus, he came to the conclusion, based on his direct experience, that all religions lead to the same goal.


In addition, through his many Sikh devotees, he learned of their faith and its great founders, and he was told of the wonderful life and teachings of the Buddha. This exposure to Sikhism and Buddhism further confirmed his experience of the universality of spiritual truth.

## Love for Humanity

Ramakrishna's love for humanity was limitless. He often said human beings were the highest manifestations of God. His disciples saw this love firsthand, and the monastic order Ramakrishna inspired achieved the distinction of being the first order in India to serve humanity. Service to God in humankind is one of the foremost ideals of the Ramakrishna Order.


Among his many other noteworthy characteristics were his universality and childlike purity, his intense sincerity, his vast knowledge of things spiritual and human (which came not from book-learning but from direct perception), and his extraordinary power to transform lives.

## Teachings & Global Influence

Ramakrishna's teachings regarding the highest truths of spiritual life were delivered in the simplest language and were punctuated by parables and homely metaphors as illustrations. Many noted writers and philosophers— Mahatma Gandhi, Leo Tolstoy, Aldous Huxley, Christopher Isherwood, Thomas Merton, Arnold Toynbee, Joseph Campbell—have been deeply impressed and influenced by him.

title: Library

sections.sectionContent:
Our library houses an extensive collection of spiritual books and literature, covering Vedanta philosophy, meditation, yoga, and the teachings of the great spiritual masters. Members and visitors are welcome to browse and borrow books for their spiritual studies.


The collection includes works by and about Sri Ramakrishna, Holy Mother Sarada Devi, Swami Vivekananda, and other direct disciples, as well as books on Hindu scriptures, comparative religion, and practical spirituality.

**For Beginners:**



- Meditation and Spiritual Life by Swami Yatiswarananda

- What Religion Is by Swami Vivekananda

- Gospel of Sri Ramakrishna (Abridged Edition)

- Bhagavad Gita (any translation with commentary)



**For Deeper Study:**



- Complete Works of Swami Vivekananda (9 volumes)

- Gospel of Sri Ramakrishna (M.'s Original)

- The Upanishads with Shankara's Commentary

- Meditation and Its Methods by Swami Vivekananda

- Jnana Yoga by Swami Vivekananda

- Bhakti Yoga by Swami Vivekananda

The library is open during our regular Sunday services (11:00 AM - 12:30 PM) and by appointment. Books may be borrowed for up to two weeks, with renewals available.


We also maintain a selection of books available for purchase at nominal cost. All proceeds go toward expanding our library collection and supporting our programs.


For more information about library access or to inquire about specific books, please contact us.



Contact Us

body:
## Our Library Collection

Our library houses an extensive collection of spiritual books and literature, covering Vedanta philosophy, meditation, yoga, and the teachings of the great spiritual masters. Members and visitors are welcome to browse and borrow books for their spiritual studies.


The collection includes works by and about Sri Ramakrishna, Holy Mother Sarada Devi, Swami Vivekananda, and other direct disciples, as well as books on Hindu scriptures, comparative religion, and practical spirituality.

## 

**For Beginners:**



- Meditation and Spiritual Life by Swami Yatiswarananda

- What Religion Is by Swami Vivekananda

- Gospel of Sri Ramakrishna (Abridged Edition)

- Bhagavad Gita (any translation with commentary)



**For Deeper Study:**



- Complete Works of Swami Vivekananda (9 volumes)

- Gospel of Sri Ramakrishna (M.'s Original)

- The Upanishads with Shankara's Commentary

- Meditation and Its Methods by Swami Vivekananda

- Jnana Yoga by Swami Vivekananda

- Bhakti Yoga by Swami Vivekananda

## Visiting Our Library

The library is open during our regular Sunday services (11:00 AM - 12:30 PM) and by appointment. Books may be borrowed for up to two weeks, with renewals available.


We also maintain a selection of books available for purchase at nominal cost. All proceeds go toward expanding our library collection and supporting our programs.


For more information about library access or to inquire about specific books, please contact us.



Contact Us

title: What is Vedanta?

sections.sectionContent:
Vedanta is one of the world's most ancient religious philosophies and one of its broadest. Based on the Vedas, the sacred scriptures of India, Vedanta affirms the oneness of existence, the divinity of the soul, and the harmony of religions. Vedanta is the philosophical foundation of Hinduism; but while Hinduism includes aspects of Indian culture, Vedanta is universal in its application and is equally relevant to all countries, all cultures, and all religious backgrounds.


A closer look at the word "Vedanta" is revealing: "Vedanta" is a combination of two words: "Veda" which means "knowledge" and "anta" which means "the end of" or "the goal of." In this context the goal of knowledge isn't intellectual—the limited knowledge we acquire by reading books. "Knowledge" here means the knowledge of God as well as the knowledge of our own divine nature. Vedanta, then, is the search for Self-knowledge as well as the search for God.

The conflicting messages we find among religions are due more to doctrine and dogma than to the reality of spiritual experience. While dissimilarities exist in the external observances of the world religions, the internals bear remarkable similarities.


Vedanta recognizes that different people have different temperaments and inclinations, and therefore require different paths to reach the same ultimate goal. All paths lead to the same summit, though some may be steeper and others more gradual. What matters is not which path one follows, but the sincerity and devotion with which one pursues it.

body:
## 

Vedanta is one of the world's most ancient religious philosophies and one of its broadest. Based on the Vedas, the sacred scriptures of India, Vedanta affirms the oneness of existence, the divinity of the soul, and the harmony of religions. Vedanta is the philosophical foundation of Hinduism; but while Hinduism includes aspects of Indian culture, Vedanta is universal in its application and is equally relevant to all countries, all cultures, and all religious backgrounds.


A closer look at the word "Vedanta" is revealing: "Vedanta" is a combination of two words: "Veda" which means "knowledge" and "anta" which means "the end of" or "the goal of." In this context the goal of knowledge isn't intellectual—the limited knowledge we acquire by reading books. "Knowledge" here means the knowledge of God as well as the knowledge of our own divine nature. Vedanta, then, is the search for Self-knowledge as well as the search for God.

## Unity in Diversity

The conflicting messages we find among religions are due more to doctrine and dogma than to the reality of spiritual experience. While dissimilarities exist in the external observances of the world religions, the internals bear remarkable similarities.


Vedanta recognizes that different people have different temperaments and inclinations, and therefore require different paths to reach the same ultimate goal. All paths lead to the same summit, though some may be steeper and others more gradual. What matters is not which path one follows, but the sincerity and devotion with which one pursues it.

title: Yoga Classes
heroSubtitle: Classical yoga for body, mind, and spirit

sections.sectionContent:
Our yoga classes focus on the classical tradition of Hatha Yoga and Raja Yoga, emphasizing the union of body, mind, and spirit. Unlike modern fitness-focused yoga, our approach integrates physical postures with breathing exercises, concentration, and meditation to support overall spiritual development.


Classes are suitable for all levels, from complete beginners to experienced practitioners. We provide individual guidance to ensure proper form and safety while helping each student deepen their practice.

Yoga classes are held weekly and are free of charge, though donations are welcome to support the program.




### Weekly Yoga Classes

Please contact us for current schedule


Class times may vary based on instructor availability and seasonal changes. Please check our calendar or contact us for the most up-to-date schedule.




View Calendar
Contact Us
In the Vedantic tradition, yoga is understood as a comprehensive spiritual path with four main approaches, each suited to different temperaments:

body:
## Classical Yoga Practice

Our yoga classes focus on the classical tradition of Hatha Yoga and Raja Yoga, emphasizing the union of body, mind, and spirit. Unlike modern fitness-focused yoga, our approach integrates physical postures with breathing exercises, concentration, and meditation to support overall spiritual development.


Classes are suitable for all levels, from complete beginners to experienced practitioners. We provide individual guidance to ensure proper form and safety while helping each student deepen their practice.

## Class Schedule

Yoga classes are held weekly and are free of charge, though donations are welcome to support the program.




### Weekly Yoga Classes

Please contact us for current schedule


Class times may vary based on instructor availability and seasonal changes. Please check our calendar or contact us for the most up-to-date schedule.




View Calendar
Contact Us

## 

In the Vedantic tradition, yoga is understood as a comprehensive spiritual path with four main approaches, each suited to different temperaments:
